p.content: All languages have the ability to express negation. This is usually achieved through the use of:

li.content: special negative degree words, such as
), or negative quantifier determiners, such as
), which express a negative nominal argument by themselves,

p.content: All of the above have been covered as individual items in previous sections (as noted). After discussing the type of negation system

uses, the data given will be reviewed here by category or phrase type. Examples of each construction used in complete sentences will be given and co-occurrence restrictions between the various negative elements will be discussed.

Languages fall into two major classifications with respect to negation: Polarity Changing languages versus Negative Concord languages, exemplified by standard English versus Spanish or Black English, respectively.

Polarity Changing languages normally allow only a single negative element in the sentence for negation to be expressed (though technically any odd number of negatives expresses negative polarity) because the presence of two (or any even number of) negative elements changes the polarity back to positive. For example,
is negative, but
is positive because it means the same as
. The version with a negative auxiliary is expressed as
, using what is known as a “negative polarity item” in object position. Such negative polarity items may occur as subjects in some contexts without any other negation present, such as
, but they may only occur in object position when some earlier element in the sentence is negative. For example, one can say
and
but without the negative subject or fronted negative adverb the negative auxiliary must be used, as in
and
p.langData: They will not find anyone anywhere

p.content: In Negative Concord languages, any number of negative elements expresses negative polarity, so in a Negative Concord version of English (such as Black English)

is the correct way to express a negative sentence with a negative object. In these languages, a negative element may normally occur in subject position or a fronted position without any other negative element present, but a negative object may only occur when some earlier element in the sentence is negative. Some Negative Concord languages have the stronger restriction that any negative word or phrase must co-occur with verbal negation and still others require fronting of the negative word or phrase, similarly to the fronting of question words or phrases in content questions.

is neither a Polarity Changing language nor a Negative Concord language, since the only way to express negation is via the verbal affix. There are not multiple instances of negation to change the polarity or to concord with.
is a

case.caseText: Polarity Changing
Negative Concord

p.content: language, since

case.caseText: the polarity changes between positive and negative with each instance of negation.
any number of negative elements simply agree in making the polarity negative.

p.content: In
, a negative-marked verb

case.caseText: is not required when the object is negative.
is required when the object is negative.
is not required when the object is negative, but if the verb is not negative then another negative word or phrase must occur earlier in the sentence.

p.content: Further,

case.caseText: a negative object simply appears in its normal position in the sentence.
fronting of the negative word or phrase is required, similar to the fronting in questions.
a negative object may appear initially in the sentence, or it may remain in its normal position.
a negative object may appear in the position directly before the verb, or it may remain in its normal position.
has
does not have any

p.content: negative polarity items.

case.caseText: The following pronouns, special degree elements, and adverbs occur in object position or the normal adverb position instead of the equivalent negative item when another negative element is present in the sentence.
The negative pronouns, special degree elements, and adverbs may occur in object position or the normal adverb position even when there is another negative element in the sentence.
has
does not have any

p.content: negative polarity items.

case.caseText: The following pronouns, determiners, and adverbs occur in object position or the normal adverb position instead of the equivalent negative item when another negative element is present in the sentence.
The negative pronouns, determiners, and adverbs may occur in object position or the normal adverb position even when there is another negative element in the sentence.

p.content: In
, a negative-marked verb

case.caseText: is not required when there is a negative-polarity item in the object position.
is required when there is a negative-polarity item in the object position.
is not required when there is a negative-polarity item in the object position, but if the verb is not negative then another negative word or phrase must occur earlier in the sentence.

there is not any negative affix which attaches to a positive auxiliary to make it negative,
and but there is a negative verbal affix.
but not nor any negative verbal affix.

p.content: Further,

case.caseText: a negative auxiliary is not allowed without the verb also being negative.
the verb is not required to be negative when there is a negative auxiliary.

p.content: A nominal phrase may normally be negated by a special degree word, such as
, or by a quantifier determiner, such as
, or by using a negative indefinite pronoun. Each type allowed in
will be exemplified in complete sentences when used as subjects and direct objects, and any restrictions will be discussed.

text.content: The use of negative polarity items in
will also be covered in section

as modifying a whole nominal phrase.
In section
we saw that in
, these are not expressed as separate words which modify the whole nominal phrase. Instead, they all attach to another word in the nominal phrase. The negative special degree elements are

case.caseText: phrasal proclitics which attach to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase.
phrasal enclitics which attach to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase.
phrasal clitics which attach either to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase or to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase.
prefixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase.
suffixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase.
either prefixes or suffixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase.

p.content: in
Since
does not have any means of negating a nominal phrase, nor any negative indefinite pronouns, it cannot have any negative objects.
As we saw in section
has negative polarity items. Therefore, a negative nominal phrase is not allowed to occur in object position. Instead, one of the negative polarity items is used and

case.caseText: the verb or auxiliary must be negative.
either the verb or auxiliary or some other element in the sentence must be negative.

As these examples show, a negative nominal phrase is
allowed to occur in object or indirect object position

case.caseText: unless the verb or auxiliary is negative.
unless either the verb or auxiliary or some other element in the sentence is negative.
without any restriction about other negative elements in the sentence.
A negative object must appear initially in the sentence, similarly to the fronting of question phrases in English.
A negative object may appear initially in the sentence, or it may remain in its normal position.
A negative object may appear in the position directly before the verb, or it may remain in its normal position.
A negative object simply appears in its normal position in the sentence, without any movement.

p.content: As these examples show, a negative polarity item is
allowed to occur in object or indirect object position

case.caseText: unless the verb or auxiliary is negative.
unless either the verb or auxiliary or some other element in the sentence is negative.
without any restriction about other negative elements in the sentence.
